message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy’s symptoms suggest autism spectrum disorder (ASD), and the diagnostic criteria do not require any specific investigations. However, it is important to conduct an extensive developmental and behavioral assessment. MRI of the brain is not indicated unless there is a concern for structural abnormalities. EEG is not routinely recommended for ASD diagnosis, and genetic testing for MECP-2 gene mutations is indicated only in specific cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of social and attention deficits, and other medical conditions have been ruled out. Thus, the most likely diagnosis is Autism Spectrum Disorder, which can be diagnosed based on clinical observation and history alone without any further testing. MRI of the brain is not routinely indicated for diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder. EEG may be helpful for diagnosing certain types of seizure disorders but is not indicated in this case. Testing for MECP-2 gene mutations is indicated only in cases where Rett Syndrome is suspected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described by the parents are consistent with a possible diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder. According to the American Academy of Pediatrics, there are no specific diagnostic tests for autism spectrum disorder and diagnosis is based on a comprehensive developmental and behavioral evaluation by a healthcare professional. Therefore, no further testing is needed at present. MRI of the brain may be useful in ruling out other conditions but is not necessary for the diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder. Electroencephalography and genetic testing for MECP-2 gene mutations are not routinely used in the diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the information provided, it is likely that the child is experiencing difficulties with social interaction and attention, which are common symptoms of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) or autism spectrum disorder (ASD). In the absence of any physical or neurologic abnormalities, further testing may not be indicated at present, and a diagnosis of ADHD or ASD may be made based on clinical evaluation and behavioral assessments. Therefore, option (D) is the most appropriate answer. MRI of brain and EEG are not routinely indicated for the evaluation of ADHD or ASD unless there are specific clinical indications or concerns. Genetic testing for MECP-2 gene mutations may be considered in cases where there is a high suspicion of Rett syndrome or other genetic disorders, but this is not indicated based on the limited information provided in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and examination findings suggest attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), which is a clinical diagnosis. No imaging, genetic or neurological testing is required at present. However, further evaluation by a specialist in ADHD may be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and initiate treatment.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of social interaction difficulty and inability to focus, but physical examination and neurologic examination are normal, and intellectual disability has been ruled out. Based on this, further testing is not necessary, and the patient could benefit from behavioral and social interventions. MRI and EEG are not indicated at this time, and genetic testing for MECP-2 gene mutations is associated with Rett syndrome, which usually presents differently in females and with more prominent developmental regression.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest possible autism spectrum disorder (ASD), which can be diagnosed based on clinical evaluation without the need for further testing. While genetic testing for MECP-2 gene mutations may be indicated in some cases of ASD, it is not necessary as a routine part of diagnostic evaluation. MRI or EEG may be indicated if there are specific neurological concerns, which are not apparent in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given the patient's normal physical and neurological examination, as well as normal audiological evaluation and ruling out intellectual disability, further testing may not be necessary at present. However, if there are other concerning symptoms or indications, investigations such as MRI or genetic testing may be indicated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The boy’s symptoms suggest that he may have attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). At this point, further testing is not necessary as ADHD is a clinical diagnosis based on symptoms and behavior. However, a referral to a pediatric psychiatrist or psychologist would be appropriate for further evaluation and management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms of autism spectrum disorder (ASD). There are no physical or neurologic abnormalities, and intellectual disability has been ruled out. Based on this information, no further testing is needed to diagnose ASD. MRI and EEG are not indicated in the diagnosis of ASD, and genetic testing is only appropriate in specific cases of suspected genetic disorders related to ASD.
